title: 106_hr1625
content:
The "Human Rights Information Act" may be cited as the short title of this legislation. The findings section of the Act is also included. The "Human Rights Information Act" emphasizes the importance of protecting and promoting human rights internationally. Federal agencies hold documents on human rights violations abroad, needed by foreign authorities for investigation and prosecution. Requests for legal assistance on human rights violations, including declassification of documents, are expected from foreign authorities. Court magistrate Baltasar Garzon requested information on General Augusto Pinochet from the United States. The US responds to declassification requests following procedures outlined in Presidential directives and executive orders. Strengthening declassification procedures, including the Freedom of Information Act, is crucial for protecting and promoting human rights globally. Expedient declassification of human rights documents will strengthen the rule of law internationally, enhance accountability of Federal agencies, and save Government resources. The United States is committed to promoting and protecting human rights and democracy globally, undertaking diplomatic, economic, and military efforts to end human rights violations. It is crucial for newly established democratic societies to investigate and prosecute human rights violations to prevent the cycle of impunity. The United States takes credible steps to investigate and prosecute human rights violations, including establishing truth commissions or tribunals, appointing human rights officers, and supporting international war crimes tribunals. The US has ratified the Convention against Torture, obligating parties to assist in criminal proceedings for acts of torture. The United States supports investigating and prosecuting human rights violations, including through truth commissions. It has ratified the Convention against Torture, which requires assisting in criminal proceedings for acts of torture. The US also endorses the recommendation for free access to information in cases of serious human rights violations. The Guatemalan peace accords, backed by the US, included an investigation into human rights violations. The Clarification Commission investigated human rights violations in Guatemala, but many questions remain unanswered. The commission recommended using all resources to find the disappeared and return their remains to relatives. Bishop Juan Jose Gerardi was assassinated after presenting a parallel investigation. President Clinton emphasized the importance of the United States supporting human rights in Guatemala. The assassination of Bishop Juan Jose Gerardi in Guatemala led President Clinton to acknowledge past mistakes in supporting repressive military forces. The National Commissioner for Human Rights in Honduras has been seeking documentation from the United States on human rights violations since 1993. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines key terms such as "human rights record," "agency," and "gross violations of internationally recognized human rights." The term "human rights record" refers to information on gross violations of human rights post-1944 held by the US Government. The term "agency" includes various US Government entities involved in foreign policy and intelligence. "Gross violations of internationally recognized human rights" is defined as per the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. SEC. 4 of the Act governs the declassification and public disclosure of human rights records regarding activities in Guatemala and Honduras after 1944. Agencies must identify, review, and organize these records for public release within 30 days of completion. The President must report to Congress on agency compliance within 150 days. An agency can delay public disclosure of a human rights record if there is clear evidence that the threat to national security outweighs the public interest, especially if it involves revealing sensitive intelligence sources or methods. The public disclosure of a human rights record can be delayed if it would impair national security, reveal confidential information, invade personal privacy, or compromise confidentiality agreements. The disclosure of a human rights record can be postponed if it would harm national security, reveal confidential information, invade privacy, or compromise confidentiality agreements. Special treatment is given to information regarding intelligence assets of the US Government, with criteria for withholding such relationships outlined. When requested by international entities or countries investigating human rights violations, US agencies must review and disclose relevant records following specified standards. Decisions to withhold records can be reviewed, considering factors like national security and confidentiality agreements. The Appeals Panel reviews agency decisions to postpone disclosure of human rights records, directing disclosure unless clear evidence shows otherwise. If disclosure is postponed, the Panel collaborates with the agency to determine next steps. The Appeals Panel collaborates with agencies to determine alternative forms of disclosure for human rights records, including disclosure of segregable portions, substitute records, or summaries. Upon completion of its review, the Panel notifies the agency head of its determination. The Appeals Panel reviews human rights records and notifies the President of its determination. The President has the authority to review the determination based on set standards within 30 days. The President must provide the Appeals Panel with a written certification of the decision within 30 days of their determination. The Appeals Panel will then publish any materials related to the postponement of disclosing a human rights record. SEC. 8. REPORT REGARDING OTHER HUMAN RIGHTS RECORDS.

The Information Security Policy Advisory Council will report to Congress on declassifying human rights records of other countries. The report will be made public.

SEC. 9. RULES OF CONSTRUCTION.

Nothing in this Act limits the right to request information from executive agencies or seek judicial review under the Freedom of Information Act.

SEC. 10. CREATION OF POSITIONS. SEC. 10. CREATION OF POSITIONS.

Two additional positions in the Appeals Panel will be created for individuals with substantial human rights expertise appointed by the President. Recommendations for these positions will be sought from nongovernmental human rights organizations.
